rubric_items.passed_description: All project code is stored in a GitHub repository and a link to the repository has been provided for reviewers. The student uses a CI tool to build the application
rubric_items.criteria: The project demonstrates an understanding of CI and Github.

rubric_items.passed_description: The README file includes introduction how to setup and deploy the project. It explains the main building blocks and has comments in the important files.
rubric_items.criteria: The project has a proper documentation.

rubric_items.passed_description: A CD tool is in place to deploy new version of the app automatically to production. The way is described and easy to follow.
rubric_items.criteria: The project use continuous deployments (CD)

rubric_items.passed_description: There is a Dockerfile in repo and the docker image can be build
rubric_items.criteria: The app is containerized

rubric_items.passed_description: On DockerHub images for the application are available
rubric_items.criteria: The project have public docker images

rubric_items.passed_description: Starting the app as a container on a local system
rubric_items.criteria: The applications runs in a container without errors

rubric_items.passed_description: The project can be deployed to a kubernetes cluster
rubric_items.criteria: The application runs on a cluster in the cloud

rubric_items.passed_description: The students can deploy a new version of the application without downtime
rubric_items.criteria: The app can be upgraded via rolling-update

rubric_items.passed_description: Two versions of the same app can run at the same and service traffic
rubric_items.criteria: A/B deployment of the application

rubric_items.passed_description: The application is monitored by Amazon CloudWatch
rubric_items.criteria: Monitoring

rubric_items.passed_description: A user of the web application can use the interface to create, delete and complete an item.
rubric_items.criteria: The application allows users to create, update, delete items

rubric_items.passed_description: A user of the web interface can click on a "pencil" button, then select and upload a file. A file should appear in the list of items on the home page.
rubric_items.criteria: The application allows users to upload a file.

rubric_items.passed_description: If you log out from a current user and log in as a different user, the application should not show items created by the first account.
rubric_items.criteria: The application only displays items for a logged in user.

rubric_items.passed_description: A user needs to authenticate in order to use an application.
rubric_items.criteria: Authentication is implemented and does not allow unauthenticated access.

rubric_items.passed_description: Code of Lambda functions is split into multiple files/classes. The business logic of an application is separated from code for database access, file storage, and code related to AWS Lambda.
rubric_items.criteria: The code is split into multiple layers separating business logic from I/O related code.

rubric_items.passed_description: To get results of asynchronous operations, a student is using async/await constructs instead of passing callbacks.
rubric_items.criteria: Code is implemented using async/await and Promises without using callbacks.

rubric_items.passed_description: All resources needed by an application are defined in the "serverless.yml". A developer does not need to create them manually using AWS console.
rubric_items.criteria: All resources in the application are defined in the "serverless.yml" file

rubric_items.passed_description: Instead of defining all permissions under **provider/iamRoleStatements**, permissions are defined per function in the **functions** section of the "serverless.yml".
rubric_items.criteria: Each function has its own set of permissions.

rubric_items.passed_description:
Application has at least some of the following:
* Distributed tracing is enabled
* It has a sufficient amount of log statements
* It generates application level metrics
rubric_items.criteria: Application has sufficient monitoring.

rubric_items.passed_description: Incoming HTTP requests are validated either in Lambda handlers or using request validation in API Gateway. The latter can be done either using the **serverless-reqvalidator-plugin** or by providing request schemas in function definitions.
rubric_items.criteria: HTTP requests are validated

rubric_items.passed_description:
1:M (1 to many) relationship between users and items is modeled using a DynamoDB table that has a composite key with both partition and sort keys. Should be defined similar to this:
```
   KeySchema:
      - AttributeName: partitionKey
        KeyType: HASH
      - AttributeName: sortKey
        KeyType: RANGE
```
rubric_items.criteria: Data is stored in a table with a composite key.

rubric_items.passed_description: Items are fetched using the "query()" method and not "scan()" method (which is less efficient on large datasets)
rubric_items.criteria: Scan operation is not used to read data from a database.
